abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome for the Second Municipal
            Infrastructure Development Project for West Bank and Gaza
            was satisfactory, the sustainability was likely, the
            institutional development impact was modest, and the Bank
            and borrower performance were both satisfactory. Lessons
            learned from the project: There is a need to be flexible and
            responsive with respect to sub-project selection and
            procurement arrangements-simplifying procedures and
            decentralizing responsibility to the extent possible. The
            issue related to lack of local contribution for water
            connections in Bidya underlines the importance of obtaining
            firm commitments from local partners prior to implementing
            components that depend on their inputs. Significant capacity
            building can be achieved even during crisis and, in fact,
            partly because of crisis. The experience with the accounting
            systems reform over two projects (MIDP-1 and 2) demonstrates
            that significant learning can take place. Significant
            progress can be made even in a very difficult environment if
            adequate local leadership exists. Building good Monitoring
            and Evaluation System including relevant set of indicators
            that enables proper monitoring, regular updating and
            capabilities of assessing impacts of projects.
